subNodes.conversationText: root
An old man with the voice of a practiced storyteller was spinning yarns in the corner of the inn.
<FirstName> stayed awhile to listen.
Unfortunately, he was just concluding.
Perhaps <FirstName> could come back some other time.

As it happened, he was already in the middle of a story about a butcher, several witches, and the butcher's goddaughter.

<FirstName> tried to follow but got lost because of the narrative's frequent detours.
Perhaps <FirstName> could come back some other time.

Alas, the storyteller had gotten into an argument with a young man in his audience.

This young man had found fault with his representation of a certain ancient hero. The storyteller accused the young man of dogmatism, and the young man accused the storyteller of dishonesty. The storyteller responded by saying that the best stories blended truth and falsehood, and the young man responded by saying that people like him were the reason the world was in such a bad way.
Perhaps <FirstName> could come back some other time.

He was just beginning a new story when, much to the young witch's disappointment, a fit of wheezing and coughing cut him off.

He motioned for a middle-aged woman sitting near him to fetch him something to drink. She brought it, and the fit passed, but he was done telling stories for the day.
Perhaps <FirstName> could come back some other time.
Fortunately for the young witch, he was just beginning a new story.
[Continue.]
"These woods have many tales, and you are probably all familiar with some of the better known ones. The mysterious Abbey of Mortal Pleasaunce, the Four Ronin, the many works of Eldest Lady..."
[Continue.]

"This one you may not know. It's about a little hill not far to the north of here, near the very center of the woods. The rare traveler who passes by it nowadays might think nothing of it, but a hundred years ago people called it Good Ghost Mound."
[Continue.]

"Desperate people used to go there. Runaways, fugitives, people who were sick or heartbroken. They would hear someone tell the legend of the hill on the way from a bad place to one they hoped would be better, and they'd go there."
"Why? What did the legends say?" asked the young witch.
"I was just getting to that," said the old man, annoyed.
[Continue.]

"The legends said that if you went to the top of the hill all by yourself, with a desperate heart, a spirit would come to you in the shape of a beautiful young person and give you something."

"If you were hungry, it would bring bread and wine like no other. If you were sick, it would bring you strange herbs. If you were heartbroken, it would bring you a deck of cards, and looking at the faces on the cards would make you forget the one who broke your heart and see the one who might make you happy."
[Continue.]
"The only thing the spirit asked for was a lock of the petitioner's hair."
[Folk Magic] "A potentially dangerous fee. A witch could do much with a lock of hair."
"Perhaps -- But in this story, the spirit was itself betrayed."
[Continue.]
"Not a very equal exchange. I suspect something sinister."
"Perhaps -- But I know of no tale of the spirit betraying a petitioner. Instead, the spirit was itself betrayed."
"Some people must have tried to appeal to the spirit by climbing the hill several times."
"That wouldn't work -- the spirit would only come if you climbed the hill with a truly desperate heart. If the spirit had already given you something, you couldn't be desperate anymore."
[Continue.]

"Having heard the stories, a traveler whose heart was desperate -- he had lost his family in a war -- climbed the hill. The spirit gave him a balm that would make him forget the atrocities he'd seen and would make the memories of his loved ones sweet, not bittersweet, in his mind."

"But when the spirit asked for some of his hair, the traveler, fearing what the spirit might do with it, gave it a lock of hair from the dog who had been his only companion."
[Continue.]

"The spirit shrieked when it touched the hair. Its face cracked. Mucus streamed from its eyes. It cried out unintelligble things in a hoarse voice, and its beautiful hair turned white. It grew old and shrank to the size of a rabbit."
 
"Then it actually became a rabbit, and the man's dog chased it down and ate it."
[Continue.]
"There is no spirit at Good Ghost Mound now, but some say that you can hear its voice if you go there with a desperate heart. No animal goes near the spot."
The witch thanked the old man for his story.
The young witch did not interrupt.

"The legends said that if you went to the top of the hill all by yourself, with a desperate heart, a spirit would come to you in the shape of a beautiful young person and give you something."

"If you were hungry, it would bring bread and wine like no other. If you were sick, it would bring you strange herbs. If you were heartbroken, it would bring you a deck of cards, and looking at the faces on the cards would make you forget the one who broke your heart and see the one who might make you happy."
Unfortunately, he was just concluding.
Perhaps <FirstName> could come back some other time.
<FirstName> moved on.
<FirstName> went back to the storyteller.
<He/She> lingered there, hoping to hear one of his tales.
Unfortunately, he was just concluding.

As it happened, he was already in the middle of a story about a butcher, several witches, and the butcher's goddaughter.

<FirstName> tried to follow but got lost because of the narrative's frequent detours.

Alas, the storyteller had gotten into an argument with a young man in his audience.

This young man had found fault with his representation of a certain ancient hero. The storyteller accused the young man of dogmatism, and the young man accused the storyteller of dishonesty. The storyteller responded by saying that the best stories blended truth and falsehood, and the young man responded by saying that people like him were the reason the world was in such a bad way.

He was just beginning a new story when, much to the young witch's disappointment, a fit of wheezing and coughing cut him off.

He motioned for a middle-aged woman sitting near him to fetch him something to drink. She brought it, and the fit passed, but he was done telling stories for the day.
Fortunately for the young witch, he was just beginning a new story.
Unfortunately, he was just concluding.
<FirstName> moved on.
